Posts.Content: Hi Kath I'm so pleased for you and your family that your little granddaughter is doing well. Very best wishes to you all.
Posts.Title: Granddaughter's op

Posts.Content: Hi Judi Thanks for sharing your experience. I'm so glad you've finally finished your treatment and can start to rebuild your life again, even though you may now be taking some form of long term medication. I was diagnosed with grade 3 invasive ductal carcinoma and DCSI in November 2013. I had surgery early December and then again early January as margins weren't clear. Unlike you I didn't have chemo as only 0.1 per cent cells were found in sentinel nodes which apparently is classed as negative. Chemo was still discussed with me because of this but oncologist said the benefits would be minimal, only 3% so I decided against it. I saw clinical oncologist on 18th March and am waiting for a call to go for planning assessment for radiotherapy, 20 sessions. The long wait adds to the anxiety. I'm also taking anastrozole and calceos. It is so valuable to read of other ladies experiences and tips on how to minimise the effects of treatment. It's fear of the unknown and reassurance from someone who's already been there really helps. Very best wishes
Posts.Title: Finished treatment

Posts.Content: Thanks ladies, your replies have eased my mind. It's probably more a fear of the unknown I suppose. I will have a 50 mile round trip and have been told it gets tiring more towards the end of treatment. I've been told it'll be for 4 weeks. Very best wishes & take care Katy
Posts.Title: CT scan for planning assessment

Posts.Content: Hi Valerie So pleased you've now had the all clear. Onwards and Upwards!
Posts.Title: CT scan for planning assessment

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies I just want to thank you all for the very helpful advice and great encouragement you gave me when I posted my fears about having a CT scan. I had my pre planning assessment today and it was absolutely fine. Everyone was really great and reassuring and I didn't feel claustrophobic at all. I start my radiotherapy on the 22nd April for 4 weeks. Thanks again and very best wishes to you all Katy
Posts.Title: CT scan for planning assessment

Posts.Content: Hi I'm going for my radiotherapy planning assessment this Wednesday and am really nervous about having a CT scan as feel claustrophobic. Any info and advice would be really appreciated. Best wishes
Posts.Title: CT scan for planning assessment

Posts.Content: Thanks Valerie I will ask. Take care Katy
Posts.Title: CT scan for planning assessment

Posts.Content: Hi Anne I'm sorry you're having so many problems with your medication. I'm taking anastrozole and have been prescribed calcium and vitamin D. Two weeks ago I was also prescribed alendronic acid as my DEXA scan showed my bones are a little thin for my age (I'm 62) and because anastrozole can affect bone density. I did have a few muscle aches in my ankles, especially after resting for a while and then moving about again. However, since taking the alendronic acid tablets I have noticed an improvement. I believe Alendronic acid is given to patients with osteoporosis or to prevent it. I take one tablet once a week. I hope my post has helped a little.
Posts.Title: Generic Anastrazole - any brand better than another and right old...

Posts.Content: Hi JMP Thanks so much for your reply. I will ask my GP for a prescription. Here's hoping Replens works for both of us. I was also told to drink lots of water. Take care & best wishes
Posts.Title: Replens MD for urine infections

Posts.Content: Thanks ladies It's good to hear from others who are going through radiotherapy at the moment and what your experiences are. I think you're right that different areas have different waiting times. My oncologist told me that the hospital I'm going to is very busy. I suppose I just want it all to finish. Take care
Posts.Title: waiting a long time for radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Has anyone used Replens vaginal gel to help prevent urine infections? I've had 3 infections since my treatment finished in May. I'm taking anastrozole and wonder if it has anything to do with it.
Posts.Title: Replens MD for urine infections

Posts.Content: Hi I was diagnosed with grade 3 invasive ductal cancer in November and had surgery beginning of December. I had to have second operation beginning of January as the margins weren't clear. There was no lymph node involvement so no chemo and am grateful for that. I am still waiting for radiotherapy to start. I saw the oncologist on 18th March who said I will hear in the next week or 2 for my planning assessment. I'm worried that it has been a long time since my operation and wondered if anyone else has had a long wait for radiotherapy. It's the waiting that seems to be the worse. I'd be really interested to hear what other ladies have experienced. Regards
Posts.Title: waiting a long time for radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hope all goes well with your radiotherapy Regards
Posts.Title: waiting a long time for radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi I finished radiotherapy on 19th May and burnt really badly with lots of blisters, my skin in parts was raw. I was given hydrogel and Activeheal foam non adhesive pads to place under my breast. The hydrogel didn't really help so GP prescribed flamazine cream which prevents infection. It was really good and helped with the healing process. My breast is still red and sore in places but the flamazine cleared the blisters. I am still washing the area with aqueous cream and using simple baby bath for the rest of my body. Sleeping topless also helps but I find applying aqueous cream about 4 times a day helps with dry patches and the itching. Best wishes to everyone here and hope all goes well for those going through or about to start radiotherapy soon.
Posts.Title: Blisters after Radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi I finished radiotherapy on 19th May and burnt really badly with lots of blisters, my skin in parts was raw. Posts.Title: Blisters after Radiotherapy

Posts.Content: I was told 4 weeks. It seems different hospitals say different things. If it's uncomfortable then leave it for a while. Take care
Posts.Title: How soon after a lumpectomy is it safe to drive?

Posts.Content: Hi I was prescribed anastrozole and was told this can affect bones so had a bone density scan. The scan showed that my bones were a little thin for my age so was prescribed calcium/vitamin D and alendronic acid. If you ring your BCN she may be able to give you the answers you need. I hope that helps. Take care and best wishes
Posts.Title: stopping tamoxifen..breast cancer
